items.title: Boom’s XB-1 becomes first civil aircraft to go supersonic
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Boom Supersonic’s XB-1 plane just went supersonic in the Mojave desert, marking it as the first civil aircraft to break the sound barrier.
- The achievement occurred during its twelfth test flight, reaching Mach 1.1 for about four minutes.
- The XB-1 is a prototype for Boom's future 64-passenger airliner called [Overture](https://boomsupersonic.com/overture).
- The supersonic flight took place eight years after XB-1 was first announced, and a second test flight could occur soon.
- Boom CEO Blake Scholl highlighted the significance of the event, comparing it to SpaceX’s first rocket reaching orbit.

items.title: Jetify launches Testpilot, its AI QA engineer
items.author: Frederic Lardinois
items.summary:
- Jetify launches AI agent named [Testpilot](https://www.jetify.com/) aimed at simplifying routine test creation.
- Currently supports web applications; mobile testing is planned for future release.
- CEO Daniel Loreto describes the launch as a pivot towards AI solutions for software development lifecycle improvement.
- AI tools handle UI testing more robustly compared to existing tools like Selenium.
- Testpilot requires only access to the application for testing, not to the underlying code repositories.

items.title: GM expects to save up to $1 billion on Cruise costs
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- General Motors anticipates up to $1 billion annual savings by halting its Cruise robotaxi program.
- CEO Mary Barra announced a restructuring to focus on personal autonomous vehicles, following an earlier decision to stop funding Cruise.
- The move comes after GM reported a $2.9 billion loss for Q4 2024, largely due to charges related to this decision, including a one-time $500 million charge and a $4 billion restructuring charge.
- Cruise expenses were reported at $400 million in the last quarter, down from $800 million in 2023.
- Most Cruise employees are uncertain about their future roles as GM integrates Cruise personnel into its main operations, with retention offers being extended to some staff.

items.title: Quibim raises $50M to develop AI models for medical imaging
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Quibim, a Spanish startup, raised $50 million in a Series A funding round to develop AI models for medical imaging.
- The company focuses on oncology, immunology, neurology, and metabolic disorders, aiming to enhance diagnostic accuracy through visual data from imaging scans.
- Quibim plans to expand its presence in the U.S. after receiving FDA clearance for its QP-Prostate product and has around 170 installations globally, collaborating with notable institutions such as Stanford University and Mass General Brigham.

items.title: Apple fixes zero-day flaw affecting all devices
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Apple released updates for iPhone, iPad, and Mac, which included switching on Apple Intelligence by default for newer devices.
- Security patches included a fix for a zero-day bug that may have been actively exploited, affecting iPhones running software older than iOS 17.2.
- The bug was found in Core Media and allowed hackers to elevate privileges and access data on devices.
- This is the first exploited bug found in iOS this year; Apple fixed at least seven similar bugs in 2024.

items.title: Hugging Face makes it easier for devs to run AI models on third-party clouds
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Hugging Face has launched Inference Providers in partnership with third-party cloud vendors like SambaNova, Fal, Replicate, and Together AI.
- The new feature allows developers to run AI models using various infrastructures easily.
- Users can deploy models without managing hardware, benefiting from automatic resource scaling by providers.
- Hugging Face provides credits for inference usage, with standard API rates for cloud provider services.

items.title: Trump says Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok
items.summary:
- President Trump announced that Microsoft is in talks to acquire TikTok's U.S. operations.
- Trump indicated there is significant interest in TikTok, with multiple bidders expected.
- Microsoft and Oracle were previously interested in acquiring TikTok in 2020 due to ownership concerns.
- Trump signed an executive order delaying the TikTok ban deadline by 75 days and advised the DOJ not to enforce penalties.
- The app remains unavailable in app stores despite being back online.
- Other bidders include Perplexity AI and billionaire Frank McCourt, with potential interest from Elon Musk and Larry Ellison.

items.title: X announces a partnership with Visa to power X Money’s wallet
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- X, owned by Elon Musk, announced a partnership with Visa for person-to-person payments for its upcoming X Money product.
- Visa Direct will be used for real-time money transfers, allowing loading money into X Money, connecting with debit cards for payments, and transferring to bank accounts.
- CEO Linda Yaccarino stated this is the first of many announcements related to X Money, which will officially debut later this year.
- Musk has previously expressed a vision to make X a financial platform, aiming for features like tipping and high-yield balances.
- X has obtained money transmitter licenses in more than 40 U.S. states for its X Payments subsidiary, indicating progress towards the launch of the payment service.

items.title: PowerSchool begins notifying students and teachers after massive data breach
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- PowerSchool is notifying individuals affected by a December 2024 data breach impacting millions in North America.
- Attackers accessed sensitive data via a compromised account, which lacked multi-factor authentication.
- Initial reports suggest up to 62 million students and 9.5 million teachers may be affected, but exact numbers are still under review.
- The breach particularly impacted the Toronto District School Board (TDSB), with almost 1.5 million students’ data stolen, including personal and medical information.
- Other affected institutions include the Calgary Board of Education, West Ada School District, and Alexandria City Public Schools, all reporting stolen personal data.

items.title: OpenAI launches ChatGPT plan for U.S. government agencies
items.summary:
- OpenAI has launched ChatGPT Gov to provide U.S. government agencies with an AI-powered chatbot platform.
- ChatGPT Gov offers capabilities from the corporate-focused ChatGPT Enterprise and allows deployment on Microsoft Azure clouds.
- Since 2024, over 90,000 users in U.S. government agencies have sent more than 18 million messages via ChatGPT to assist in their work.

items.title: Alice&Bob raises $104M, says quantum computers based on cat qubits will be ready by 2030
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Alice&Bob, a Paris startup, raised €100 million ($104 million) in Series B funding.
- The funds will be used to develop a fault-tolerant quantum computer based on cat qubits, expected to be ready by 2030.
- The investment is co-led by Future French Champions, AVP, and Bpifrance, marking one of the largest rounds for a quantum startup in Europe.
- CEO Théau Peronnin notes a shift in the industry aligning with their vision of building quantum computers.
- Notable trends in the quantum sector include other startups securing significant funding and advances in quantum error correction.

items.title: ‘Blade’ writer David S. Goyer debuts his latest sci-fi franchise on Incention, a new platform built on Story blockchain
items.author: David S. Goyer
items.summary:
• The article discusses the emergence of “tokenized storytelling” in entertainment, allowing fan participation in story development.
• David S. Goyer has partnered with Incention to launch a new sci-fi franchise called “Emergence,” utilizing blockchain technology.
• Incention aims to protect IP and enhance fan engagement in the creative process, allowing fans to contribute narratives, art, and music.
• Starting today, fans can collaborate on Emergence, voting on ideas that may become part of the official canon.
• Goyer's story centers around a white hole called the “White Fountain,” releasing powerful relics across the galaxy.
• An AI agent named “Atlas” has been developed to assist collaborators in generating ideas and ensuring narrative accuracy.
• Future voting opportunities for fans include character fates and new character introductions, with a leaderboard for tracking contributions.

items.title: Spotify says it paid $10 billion to music industry last year
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Spotify paid $10 billion to the music industry in the last year.
- Since its inception, the total payouts amount to nearly $60 billion.
- The company aims to counter claims of insufficient artist reward and highlights that payouts include payments to publishers and other partners.
- Over 500 million people are paying customers of music streaming worldwide; Spotify has 252 million subscribers.
- More than 60% of Spotify users are on the ad-supported free tier.
- The company has seen over 10,000 artists earning over $100,000 annually from streaming.

items.title: Lucid Gravity SUV owners will gain access to Tesla Superchargers on Jan 31
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Owners of the electric Lucid Gravity SUV will have access to Tesla’s Supercharging network starting January 31.
- The Gravity is the second model from Lucid, featuring charge ports compatible with Tesla’s North American Charging Standard (NACS).
- Lucid Air owners will access Tesla Superchargers via adapters in the second quarter of 2025.
- Several automakers are adopting Tesla's charging standard for future EV models, and adapters are being provided for CCS port vehicles.
- Lucid’s new 926V powertrain allows the Gravity to charge at speeds of up to 400 kW on 1000V charging equipment.

items.title: ENGlobal says hackers accessed ‘sensitive personal’ data during cyberattack
items.summary:
- U.S. engineering firm ENGlobal reported that hackers accessed 'sensitive personal information' during a November 2024 cyberattack.
- The attack led to the encryption of some data files, indicating a potential ransomware incident.
- Business applications, including financial reporting systems, were offline for approximately six weeks.
- The company has not disclosed the number of individuals affected or the types of data accessed but plans to notify those impacted.
- ENGlobal stated its operations are now 'fully restored' and believes the hackers no longer have access to its IT systems.

items.title: Atomicwork Secures Khosla Ventures Backing for AI-Driven IT Software
items.author: Vijay Rayapati, Kiran Darisi, Parsuram Vijayasankar
items.summary:
- Atomicwork, a SaaS startup, raised $25 million backed by Khosla Ventures to enhance AI-driven IT service management.
- The platform allows quick implementation of automated service workflows, reducing traditional multi-year setups to weeks.
- Founded in 2022, the startup has raised over $38 million, targeting enterprises with $1 billion revenue and 1,000+ employees.
- It utilizes existing LLM models for automation and prioritizes data security with options for enterprise-owned encryption keys.
- Currently serves eight customers, mostly in the U.S., and aims to enhance AI R&D and integrations with major firms like Oracle and SAP.

items.title: Helion raises $425M to help build a fusion reactor for Microsoft
items.summary:
- Helion, a fusion startup, raised $425 million, achieving a valuation of $5.245 billion.
- The company plans to supply Microsoft with electricity by 2028, ahead of competitors.
- Helion's new prototype, Polaris, aims to be the first fusion reactor to generate electricity, with significant engineering challenges ahead.
- CEO David Kirtley emphasizes the need for in-house manufacturing capabilities to meet production timelines.
- The current reactor design will generate 50 megawatts of electricity, with potential for higher frequencies in the future.
- Investors include Sam Altman and SoftBank Vision Fund 2, among others.

items.title: Microsoft tests ‘scareware blocker’ for Edge that uses computer vision to detect scams
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Microsoft introduces a new ‘scareware blocker’ for the Edge browser using machine learning and computer vision to identify online scams.
- Scareware typically manifests as fake antivirus software tricking users into downloading malicious programs.
- The tool is designed to block unknown scams that try to launch full-screen pages, which are often difficult to exit.
- Microsoft previously showcased the blocker during its Ignite conference in November and is now inviting users to test it through a preview program.
- It aims to enhance existing security features by intervening with audio and screen issues related to suspects scams.
- The machine learning model operates locally on users’ machines without saving data to the cloud, addressing potential privacy concerns.

items.title: Zepto shifts domicile to India as local listings gain appeal
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Zepto has shifted its domicile from Singapore to India, joining a trend of Indian startups relocating ahead of public listings.
- This shift is noted as the fastest domicile transition by a foreign-headquartered startup to India.
- The easier process for domicile shifts was facilitated by the Indian authorities, leading many startups to move back home for better access to local capital markets.
- Prominent Indian startups like PhonePe and Groww have also relocated their headquarters in recent years.
- Zepto, valued at $5 billion, aims to raise up to $1.1 billion in an upcoming IPO this year, having raised over $1.35 billion last year.

items.title: TravelPerk raises $200M as valuation nearly doubles to $2.7B
items.summary:
- TravelPerk, a Barcelona-based business travel management platform, raised $200 million at a valuation of $2.7 billion, nearly doubling its previous $1.4 billion valuation.
- The company acquired Swiss startup Yokoy to enhance its offerings with native expenses management.
- The business travel sector is expected to reach a record $1.5 trillion in 2024, surpassing pre-pandemic levels, prompting interest from investors in corporate travel startups.

items.title: Google Maps will soon rename Gulf of Mexico to ‘Gulf of America’
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google will change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to the 'Gulf of America' in Google Maps, following an executive order by President Trump.
- The name changes will only apply to U.S. users, as Google Maps displays contested geographic names according to each country's official naming conventions.
- Denali, the highest peak in North America, will revert to its former name, Mount McKinley, for all users worldwide, despite prior renaming during the Obama administration.

items.title: Reid Hoffman’s Manas AI raises $24.6M, a fraction of other AI drug discovery startups
items.author: Reid Hoffman, Siddhartha Mukherjee
items.summary:
- LinkedIn founder Reid Hoffman and cancer researcher Siddhartha Mukherjee co-founded Manas AI, focusing on AI-powered drug discovery.
- The startup raised $24.6 million in seed funding from Hoffman, General Catalyst, and Greylock.
- Manas AI’s funding is significantly lower compared to other AI drug discovery startups, such as Xaira's $1 billion and Treeline Biosciences's $422 million raised.
- The company will initially target breast cancer, prostate cancer, and lymphoma, aiming to design and test molecules using AI in collaboration with Microsoft Azure.
- The founders emphasize the significance of AI in the drug development process, with Hoffman having historical ties to Microsoft.

items.title: Former Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger is already using DeepSeek instead of OpenAI at his startup, Gloo
items.summary:
- DeepSeek introduced an open source AI reasoning model, R1, boosting its consumer app to the top of app stores.
- Pat Gelsinger, former CEO of Intel, has opted for DeepSeek over OpenAI for his startup Gloo's AI service, Kallm.
- Gelsinger claims R1 is significantly cheaper, estimating it to be 10-50x less expensive to train than OpenAI's existing models.

items.title: SonicWall says hackers are exploiting a new zero-day bug to breach customer networks
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- SonicWall reports a zero-day vulnerability in the SMA1000 remote access appliance is being exploited by hackers.
- The vulnerability, CVE-2025-23006, allows malware installation without system login.
- Several thousand SMA 1000 devices are vulnerable, urging users to apply available security patches.
- The bug was discovered by Microsoft and confirmed as actively exploited, affecting various corporate networks.
- Cybersecurity products are increasingly targeted by hackers due to inherent vulnerabilities.

items.title: Quartz has been quietly publishing AI-generated news articles
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
- Quartz has begun publishing AI-generated articles, aggregating reports from other outlets including TechCrunch.
- The initiative started with simple earnings reports and has expanded to short articles, with 18 AI-generated pieces published as of Monday afternoon.
- Each article is around 400 words and cites sources only at the top, lacking full quotes and attributions typical in traditional journalism.
- A spokesperson confirmed that the AI newsroom is “purely experimental,” with editorial staff reviewing each piece before publication.
- The experimental AI has previously faced criticism for quality issues in reporting, reflecting broader concerns about AI-generated content in media.

items.title: How to switch off Apple Intelligence on your iPhone, iPad, and Mac
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Apple released software updates including iOS 18.3, opting users into [Apple Intelligence](https://techcrunch.com/tag/apple-intelligence/).
- Users may wish to disable AI features due to concerns about the [environment](https://www.unep.org/news-and-stories/story/ai-has-environmental-problem-heres-what-world-can-do-about#:~:text=But%20when%20it%20comes%20to,becoming%20scarce%20in%20many%20places.) or [political views](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/13/sam-altman-and-jeff-bezos-are-the-latest-billionaires-to-donate-1m-to-trump-fund/) in the industry.
- To switch off Apple Intelligence: Go to *Settings* on iOS or *System Settings* on Mac, then tap or click on *Apple Intelligence*, and toggle it off. Confirm the action in the dialog that appears.
- On iOS, find *Apple Intelligence & Siri*, toggle the switch to turn it off and consider disabling Siri for privacy reasons.
- Apple claims its AI features are designed with privacy in mind, utilizing a system called [Private Cloud Computer](https://techcrunch.com/2024/10/24/apple-will-pay-security-researchers-up-to-1-million-to-hack-its-private-ai-cloud/).

items.title: DeepSeek claims its ‘reasoning’ model beats OpenAI’s o1 on certain benchmarks
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Chinese AI lab DeepSeek has launched an open reasoning model, DeepSeek-R1, which claims to perform on par with OpenAI’s o1 on certain benchmarks.
- R1 is available on [Hugging Face](https://huggingface.co/deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1) under an MIT license for commercial use.
- It reportedly surpasses o1 in benchmarks like AIME, MATH-500, and SWE-bench Verified.
- The model has 671 billion parameters, with smaller distilled versions also released.
- R1 is cheaper than OpenAI’s o1, priced 90%-95% lower.
- Over 500 derivative models of R1 have been created, totaling 2.5 million downloads.
- R1 has restrictions on sensitive topics due to Chinese regulatory guidelines, such as avoiding questions about Tiananmen Square.
- The launch coincides with proposed harsher restrictions on exporting AI technologies to China by the Biden administration.

items.title: Nvidia drops $600B off its market cap amid the rise of DeepSeek
items.author: Becca
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI startup, released its R1 model, impacting Nvidia's market performance.
- Nvidia's stock fell 16.9%, losing nearly $600 billion in market cap; closed at $118.58 after previously being $142.62.
- R1's efficiency and effectiveness signal that advanced AI models can be built with less costly hardware, alarming Nvidia.
- Recent changes in U.S. AI chip export policies following Biden's executive order, which was reversed by Trump, add to the market dynamics.

items.title: Alibaba’s Qwen team releases AI models that can control PCs and phones
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Alibaba's Qwen team released the Qwen2.5-VL AI models for text and image analysis, including tasks like file parsing and object counting.
- The models can control PCs, outperforming competitors like OpenAI's Operator and others in video understanding and document analysis.
- Qwen2.5-VL models are available for testing and download, but include restrictions on discussing certain topics due to Chinese regulations.
- The flagship model, Qwen2.5-VL-72B, requires permission for commercial use from Alibaba if companies have over 100 million monthly active users.

items.title: Cornell’s robot jellyfish and worm are powered by a hydraulic fluid battery
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Researchers at Cornell University showcased bio-inspired robots powered by a hydraulic fluid battery on January 27, 2025. 
- The robots include a modular worm and a jellyfish that utilize embodied energy to reduce weight and cost. 
- The jellyfish's runtime has been extended to 1.5 hours using the new battery technology, which integrates power generation and movement. 
- The hydraulic fluid acts as both the energy source and propulsion mechanism, allowing lifelike movements similar to natural jellyfish. 
- Modular segments in the worm facilitate locomotion and adaptability for underwater and land environments.

items.title: Hackers are targeting machine identities. Token Security just raised $20M to stop them
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Token Security raised $20 million in Series A funding to enhance machine identity security.
- The startup’s creation was inspired by security risks from outdated or excessive access of service accounts.
- Token Security’s platform identifies machine identities and helps prevent potential breaches.
- Key founder Itamar Apelblat experienced security flaws in a previous job involving service accounts.
- The company plans to relocate headquarters to the U.S. to tap into a larger enterprise security market.
- Machine identity security is gaining attention, with significant funding and acquisitions in the field recently.

items.title: Smartwatch pioneer and Kickstarter darling Pebble is returning in a new form
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- After filing for insolvency in 2016 and being sold to Fitbit, Pebble creator Eric Migicovsky announces a revival of the brand.
- Migicovsky plans to create a new smartwatch, leveraging the open-sourced PebbleOS from Google to support further development.
- The new smartwatch aims to feature an always-on e-paper screen, long battery life, and a hackable design, emphasizing user-centric features over flashy technology.
- Initial production will be self-funded, as Migicovsky does not plan to seek venture capital or use Kickstarter again.
- The Pebble brand still has an active community, indicating continued interest despite competition from major players like Apple.

items.title: DeepSeek displaces ChatGPT as the App Store’s top app
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, from a Chinese AI lab, became the No. 1 app in global app stores, surpassing ChatGPT.
- As of January 26, DeepSeek was the No. 1 free app on iOS in the U.S. and in 51 other countries.
- The app doubled its downloads from 1 million to 2.6 million within a few days, primarily driven by its new AI models.
- It ranked in the Top 10 for free apps in 111 countries on the App Store and 18 countries on Google Play.
- Daily active users rose over 110% from January 24 to 25 compared to the previous week.
- Despite most downloads occurring in China, the U.S. accounts for 15% of its downloads.
- DeepSeek's rise questions the stability of dominant consumer AI apps like ChatGPT and Gemini.
- Apple’s algorithm may influence app rankings based on install velocity, not just total downloads.
- The tech industry is analyzing DeepSeek's training techniques and facing pressure as a result.
- DeepSeek experienced “large-scale malicious” attacks, limiting registration for users outside of China.

items.title: How DeepSeek’s efficient AI could stall the nuclear renaissance
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- DeepSeek has released its R1 model, competing with AI leaders despite using fewer GPUs.
- The efficiency of DeepSeek raises questions about the necessity of high hardware expenditures in AI.
- The rise in power demand from AI could shift energy demands away from new nuclear projects, which have been on the rise due to advances in technology.
- Major tech companies like Google, Amazon, and Microsoft are investing heavily in nuclear and renewable energy to meet anticipated energy needs.
- Analysts are skeptical about whether DeepSeek’s efficiency can be sustained without advanced GPUs, suggesting trends in the AI field are shifting toward improved model efficiency instead.

items.title: OpenAI-backed 1X acquires Kind Humanoid
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- 1X has acquired Kind Humanoid, a Norwegian robotics startup.  
- The acquisition signals a pivotal moment for the humanoid robotics industry ahead of 2025.  
- Kind Humanoid previously collaborated with designer Yves Behar to develop its first commercial robot.  
- The deal enhances 1X's ability to create safe and intelligent humanoids, aligning with its vision to integrate humanoids into daily life.  
- Financial details of the acquisition have not been disclosed.

items.title: Bluesky adds video to user profiles
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Social network Bluesky introduces a new video tab for user profiles to showcase uploaded videos.
- This follows the recent addition of a TikTok-like video feed, enhancing the platform's video capabilities.
- The videos can be original or sourced from other platforms, including TikTok, and could generate potential revenue for Bluesky.
- Some users express concerns about the platform becoming a TikTok rival and request options to disable the video tab.
- Development interest is growing, with creators working on various video-centric apps for Bluesky.
- The change was made in the Bluesky 1.97 update, which also included user blocking features and other improvements.

items.title: AI startup DeepSeek pauses signups amid cyber incident
items.summary:
- DeepSeek pauses new user registrations due to a cyberattack.
- Existing users can still access their accounts without issues.
- This follows recent excitement about its open-source R1 model that claims to outperform OpenAI's o1 on multiple benchmarks.
- DeepSeek's app achieved 2.6 million downloads, with 1 million occurring last Friday.

items.title: Viral AI company DeepSeek releases new image model family
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- DeepSeek launches new multimodal AI models under the name Janus Pro, claiming superior performance to OpenAI’s DALL-E 3.
- The models are available for download on [Hugging Face](https://huggingface.co/organizations/deepseek-ai/activity/all) and range from 1 billion to 7 billion parameters, designed for both analyzing and creating images.
- Janus Pro models excel at generating small images (up to 384 x 384 resolution) and compete well against existing models like PixArt-alpha and Stability AI's Stable Diffusion XL.

items.title: Grok 3 seemingly went live for some users
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Grok 3, a new AI model from xAI, may be nearing its release as some users access it on X.
- Users reported that Grok 3 could respond to logical reasoning queries and coding tasks, despite some errors.
- Elon Musk had previously indicated that Grok 3 would be released in January or early February 2025 after missing its initial deadline.

items.title: Meta AI can now use your Facebook and Instagram data to personalize its responses
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Meta AI rolls out improvements including a memory feature that allows it to remember user details across conversations.
- Users can personalize interactions by telling Meta AI what they like, while the bot will use data from Facebook, Messenger, and Instagram to offer tailored recommendations.
- The personalized features will go live in the U.S. and Canada, but there won't be an option to opt-out of data use.

items.title: TechCrunch Disrupt 2025: 5 Days Left for 2 for 1 Passes at Lowest Rate of the Year
items.summary:
- Only 5 days left to claim 2 for 1 Passes for TechCrunch Disrupt 2025.
- Passes available at the lowest rates, saving up to $1,400.
- Special offer ends on January 31 at 11:59 PM PT.
- Event dates: October 27–29 at Moscone West, San Francisco.
- Features 250+ sessions, networking opportunities, and Startup Battlefield 200.
- Highlights emerging trends and innovations in the tech industry, especially AI.

items.title: How the ransomware attack at Change Healthcare went down: A timeline
items.summary:
- A February 2024 ransomware attack on Change Healthcare is the largest data breach of health and medical data in U.S. history.
- Change Healthcare confirmed in January 2025 that the breach affects approximately 190 million Americans, almost doubling earlier estimates.
- The company processed billing for a vast number of hospitals and medical practices, holding sensitive medical data for potentially half of the U.S. population.
- February 21, 2024: Systems went down leading to a network shut down to isolate cyber intruders.
- February 29, 2024: UnitedHealth identified the attack as from the ALPHV/BlackCat ransomware gang.
- March 3-5, 2024: UnitedHealth paid a $22 million ransom, but the hackers disappeared without returning the stolen data.
- March 13, 2024: The American Medical Association expressed concerns about ongoing disruptions in healthcare services due to the attack.
- April 15, 2024: An affiliate of the hackers formed a new gang and published some of the stolen data as part of a new ransom demand.
- April 22, 2024: UnitedHealth confirmed a significant proportion of health data was stolen, first acknowledging the scale of the breach.
- May 1, 2024: UnitedHealth's CEO testified that basic cybersecurity measures were not in place to prevent the attack.
- June 20, 2024: Change Healthcare began notifying affected individuals, legally required under HIPAA, about the data stolen.
- July 29, 2024: Notifications were mailed to individuals confirming the stolen data included their health and medical information.

items.title: Lydian Labs can make aviation fuel wherever there’s CO2 and electricity
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Lydian Labs is developing a method to create jet fuel from CO2 and electricity as a means to curb aviation's carbon emissions.
- The company's approach involves using efficient catalysts and flexible operation of reactors to reduce fuel production costs.
- A pilot plant in North Carolina can produce up to 25 gallons of e-fuel per day, significantly increasing outputs compared to earlier attempts.
- Lydian plans to complete a commercial-scale plant by 2027 and is exploring applications in military fuel supply.

items.title: Mistral’s origin story has an insuretech founder at its heart
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Mistral, a French AI startup, is valued at $6 billion and is a major player in foundation models in Europe.
- Jean-Charles Samuelian-Werve, CEO of Alan, is a co-founding advisor at Mistral, instrumental in its growth and funding.
- Samuelian-Werve foresaw the AI boom and shifted focus from a non-profit to co-founding Mistral; Alan continues to invest in AI services.

items.title: DeepSeek ‘punctures’ tech spending plans, and what analysts are saying
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI firm, aims to challenge U.S. AI leaders with advanced models at lower costs.
- Its mobile app topped charts in key markets including the U.S., UK, and China shortly after launch in January 2025.
- Wall Street's reaction is mixed; Jefferies warns of impacts on capital expenditures in AI, while Goldman Sachs sees potential shifts in competition between tech giants and startups.

items.title: TalkTalk investigating data breach after hacker claims theft of customer data
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- TalkTalk is investigating a data breach involving stolen personal information of millions of customers.
- A hacker, using the alias ‘b0nd’, claims to have stolen data of over 18.8 million current and former subscribers, including names, email addresses, and subscriber PINs.
- TalkTalk disputes the hacker's claim, stating the number is significantly overstated, with approximately 2.4 million actual customers.
- The breach is linked to unexpected access of a third-party supplier’s system, though no financial data was compromised.
- TalkTalk previously faced a £400,000 fine for a 2015 breach where hackers accessed data of 157,000 customers, including financial details.

items.title: Perplexity submits a new bid for TikTok
items.summary:
- Perplexity AI has submitted a revised proposal to merge with TikTok, aiming to give the U.S. government up to 50% ownership of the new entity.
- The proposal includes a government stake after an IPO of at least $300 million and potential continued ownership for ByteDance.
- The bid was revised based on feedback from President Trump's administration, amidst ongoing discussions about TikTok's ownership and regulation in the U.S.

items.title: DeepSeek gets Silicon Valley talking
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Chinese AI company DeepSeek released an open version of its reasoning model R1, sparking discussions in the tech community.
- R1 matches or beats OpenAI's o1 model on certain benchmarks, with training costs reportedly only $5.6 million.
- DeepSeek's success was achieved despite U.S. sanctions on advanced chips for Chinese companies, raising concerns about its implications for American AI firms.
- Industry reactions include support from venture capitalists and skepticism from others who question the authenticity of the company's claims.
- DeepSeek's AI assistant has become the top free app in the Apple App Store, surpassing ChatGPT as of Sunday.

items.title: Why Reid Hoffman feels optimistic about our AI future
items.author: Reid Hoffman, Greg Beato
items.summary:
- Reid Hoffman’s new book *Superagency* argues that AI can enhance human agency, leading to better knowledge and improved lives.
- Hoffman emphasizes the importance of 'smart risk taking' over blind optimism regarding technology.
- He supports intelligent regulation but believes with iterative deployment, AI tools can be improved through continuous user feedback.
- Discussion includes the benefits of AI, its societal impacts, and categorizing different perspectives on AI (bloomers, gloomers, doomers).
- AI's role in society is framed as one that can provide collective advantages, exemplifying how innovation leads to safety and agency.

items.title: 2025 will likely be another brutal year of failed startups, data suggests
items.summary:
- In 2024, 966 startups shut down, a 25.6% increase from 769 in 2023.
- AngelList reported 364 startup winddowns in 2024, a 56.2% jump from 233 in 2023.
- Most shutdowns attributed to high valuations and lack of product-market fit, leading to cash shortages.
- Projections indicate continued shutdowns in early 2025, with a gradual decline expected later in the year.
- Majority (60%) of startups that fail do not have enough capital to return to investors.
